title: Seventy-two years after Independence, millions of Indians seek freedom in foreign lands
text:
In a shameful indictment of 72 years of misgovernance since the country gained Independence from colonial raj 311 Indian nationals have been deported from Mexico where they smuggled themselves in a desperate attempt to enter the US in the hope of a better life.

Most of the deportees are youths, mainly from Punjab and Haryana, which are among the more prosperous of the Indian states.

One young man said he travelled through seven countries, marched for several days through the jungles of Panama, where he saw a number of corpses of ill-fated migrants like himself, before reaching Mexico, where he was apprehended by the local authorities, along with 310 other compatriots.

The only woman among the deportees claimed that she had spent Rs 53 lakhs trying to get herself, her husband, and her son into the US. These 311 deportees are only a tiny trickle of the vast flood of Indians who illegally, and often unsuccessfully, attempt to enter the US, or other countries, where they believe they’ll have a brighter future.

Even as the current government talks about India being within sight of becoming a five trillion dollar economy, millions of Indians seek to escape the imprisonment of poverty in the country of their birth and seek freedom from economic oppression in a foreign country, and under foreign rule.

India threw off the galling yoke of British rule 72 years ago. But it seems it still has to free itself from the shackles of deprivation and despair in which the sins of omission and commission of successive regimes have fettered only too many of its supposedly free citizens. A bitter truth to which the 311 deportees bear tragic witness.
